4xX1wEpxcIFiicluU87H4Q.text: First time trying Malasian Food.  I love most Asian cuisines, and based on Yelp reviews I thought this would be an ace in the hole.  Food was okay, but nothing really stood out.

kd57WgNLkczhRhEUzjRecA.text: Some of the  best Malaysian food I ever had (and I have been to Malaysia). The location is great and the prices are very reasonable.Food: 5/5Location: 5/5Service: 3/5Proces: 3/5

b7LVni4G1nKiC4kLRLBg8Q.text: Yee Gan brought us to this delicious Malaysian place in Chinatown. I don't have much knowledge of Malaysian food but it reminded me of most of the no frills Chinese restaurants I always go to at home. We were caught in torrential downpour before we came here. So a nice warm meal was in order. After 4 mains and a starter, I came away with a nice pot belly and a wallet that wasn't ravaged. It met the 3 G's Good price, good food, good people = 4 stars!

OGWTwMHKB8-X-XzTWjCiCQ.text: It has been a long time since I've been to Rasa Sayang, but I remember it almost as clearly as the day I went. Fortunately, "review drafts" help with triggering vital memories, such as the torrential downpour of the unfortunate day we chose to go (but then again, isn't London almost constantly in a perpetual state of downpour??), or the flavorful savory carrot cake I ordered AFTER I finished my entire entree AND nitpicked off of my friend's leftovers. If anyone has had dim sum before, the savory carrot cake is a tremendously tastier version of lau bak goh (turnip cake). it's definitely heavier than most of the other dishes at Rasa Sayang, but somehow I managed to polish it off mostly by myself after I devoured every edible piece of flesh off my Fish Assam (also delicious, if a bit meager)I guess the only dishes I could have done without were the Singapore fried rice & the vermicelli noodles, which I probably would not have ordered on my own anyway. Nothing wrong with either of them, but they cannot compare (even in the menu pictures!) to the chili crab, nasi lemak, or ANY Of the more interesting dishes! I think even if you knew nothing about Malaysian food (which I cannot claim expertise in, but still mosied my way through the menu) you can still find plenty of gems to keep you coming back to Rasa Sayang.

Q07TK5PU-30jFWBxkQU4Sw.text: YUMMMMM legit Malaysian & Singaporean food :) Laksa!!!! Also, it's relatively cheap. Can't wait to go back.

SRPqgNy7ddj9JvCNM_wVwg.text: I really want to give it 4 stars but it just hasn't left that much of an impression on me..Being the expert on Malaysian food, Yee Gan ordered for 4 of us. We had a couple curry dishes, hainan chicken, the beef hufun dish, and for 5 main courses it came out to 4 very full people at £10/each. For the value, I think it's a great place to try Malaysian, and everything tasted "good," but personally, I didn't really feel much of a party starting on my tongue.

nRW448nx-anVM5K7RPVE5w.text: This place is the bomb !!!! It is fantastic for the price you pay... Try theirTeh TarekNasi LemakChili CrabFried Fish in SambalDo not try their Beef Rendang ( it is very over cooked, Kiasu makes better ones )Curry Puffs ( Very Oily, Kiasu makes better ones ) I left this resturant very suprised. It was like my tounge had an exotic booty call. It was lovely. Check it out ...

uoeKkZjupI3E4o_yUvi9Wg.text: If you want to use a card, make sure it is of the PIN/Chip variety.  I would have tried everything on the menu.  This place reminded me of the great meals I had in Penang and they didn't dumb anything down in their preparation.  Red curry was a standout dish.  Char Mee could have been a little spicier.

DSYhVFEcIFIaRgePJW5suA.text: Well, that was amazing!!! Sangat bagus!

6wAVRGAaZFeowhV1dVF2PQ.text: I also went with Chieh Roger and Yee Gan...I haven't had too much Malaysian but I thought the food was very good.  and although the place was pretty crowded the food came out really quick (which is always a plus with me).  I thought the curries we had were seasoned well.  just enough spice.  and it was decently priced at about 10 pounds per person.

nhOYimLYMKVWRaufKV5w_w.text: Good quality food for a reasonable price. Definately worth a try if it's your first time for trying Malaysian food.

fGEPyzRO4RNUeMTIFaEPBQ.text: the food there was really great - not many veggie options for my best mate who is a veggie by choice! I was very happy with my food there. I loved their milo dinosaur drink - a real classic (quite popular in Singapore it appears). I will come back with everyone I can think of :-)

yEwry5bXdxAjHQ5RioLvRg.text: I've never understood why the Straits cuisine of Malaysia and Singapore isn't more popular. Given the popularity of Chinese, Indian and Thai food in the UK, you'd have thought it'd be a winner especially as it has much in common with all three. Whilst Indian is the traditional choice for post-pub dining, I reckon Straits cuisine would make for great way to end the evening. To put this theory to the test, I met up with my old mate, the Italian Shetland Pony, his missus and a few other muckers on a pre-Christmas Friday night out. After a few beers in Soho  all in the cause of research  we pitched up at Rasa Sayang sometime after 11pm. Being a bit of a control freak, I took charge and ordered some sides to share - 3 portions of roti canai, a portion of curry cheong fan (both pictured above) and 2 portions of spring rolls. The coconutty curry sauce in the first two dishes was really zingy and I wish I ordered more of the cheong fan as these rice noodles were very more-ish. For the mains, I let people order their own - I had beef rendang (pictured above)  spicy yet with the distinct taste of the coconut milk coming through. ISP ordered a giant bowl of curry laksa (photo at top) and I guess he enjoyed it as he soon polished it off. Other mains included nasi lemak and a couple of dishes that I didn't make a proper note of  one was a stir fried noodle dish of Hokkien origins and the other was a chicken curry served with roti. A great end to a great evening - Straits cuisine is ideal for late night dining be you sober or drunk. Rasa Sayang is far superior to your average late night ruby and much better value too. The damage was a mere £14/head including service and a round of drinks. Update - July 2010 A quick mention for my favourite dish here, fried fish vermicelli (£6.90). In Cantonese, this dish is called yu tou fen, which translates as fish head vermicelli ! As well as the fried fish head, this dish includes fried fish, preserved veg, tomatoes, tung choi (morning glory), and rice vermicelli in a broth topped with fried shallots and spring onion. As with many of the best soup noodle dishes, it's the broth that makes the dish. In this case, the milky broth is different class, with fishy undertones cut through with the almost medicinal qualities of Chinese wine/tonic. This is a if Carlsberg did noodles bowl of noodles and whilst fish head may not be to all tastes, it is in my opinion, one of the finest noodle dishes in London. eatlovenoodles.blogspot.…

htgiCO8GcPZ8LBN2yjxYMQ.text: When you are hungry and you are dead tired of the meager portions, head to Chinatown.  Here I got something filling and delish for little money.  I was extremely happy when I was lured here.  The food is approachable and very good.  The portions are smaller, compared to American standards, but larger than the European.  The roti and the chicken dishes that the waiter recommended was cooked and seasoned nicely.  This experience had left me with a favorable impression on Malaysian cuisine.

lSLFD4ZWvwV0G-SLUEXGnw.text: It's cheap and good and tasty. Just not as authentic as it should be.

DsPcwQRd-bMhzJy4T_o8XQ.text: Rasa Sayang - Pics @ The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) Besides San Francisco and Shanghai, there is only one other place that I feel can rival London's culinary diversity, and that is Singapore. I would gladly take a 12-hour flight to be able to eat there. The countless food courts, their wonderful Chilli Crab, the oyster omelettes that melt in your mouth, are just some of the many reasons why I keep going back. I love Singapore, and in my latest trip, I also discovered the most delicious Straits Chinese food. I first came across the concept of Straits Heritage Cuisine a few years ago in Malacca, former capital of Malaysia. Straits Chinese food can refer to the cuisine that has evolved from the inter-racial marriages of descendants of late 15th and 16th century Chinese immigrants with natives of the region of Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia. Peranakan and Baba-Nyonya are also the commonly used terms in Malay to describe this marriage of cultures and food. Needless to say, that the food is superb, complex, and richly flavoured with regional spices and pastes. Rasa Sayang is not entirely Nyonya. Their menu is predominantly Malaysian/Singaporean hawker street food, and contains some of these nations' favourite dishes like Chilli Crab, Char Kuay Teow and Pan-fried Carrot Cake. I was glad however to see some of my favourite Nyonya dishes in the menu like Ayam Sambal (chicken stewed in rich coconut curry) and Stir Fried Sambal Cluster Beans. It was with much anticipation that I arranged to visit Rasa Sayang with my delightful Malaysian friend Charmaine Chow and her partner. I have been lucky enough to have experienced Charmaine's Malaysian cooking a number of times, and knew that I would be in very good hands when ordering. Rasa Sayang is simply decorated, aiming at functionality as opposed to style or comfort. The restaurant is small and the lighting is searingly bright. This is not a place designed to be restful but more like a canteen or a shopping mall eatery with a high turnover of customers and pushy waitresses. We started with Hainanese Chicken with rice (£6.90) which we both agreed was very tender and succulent. I love the simplicity of this dish and the fact that the flavours come mostly from the delicious broth the chicken is cooked in. The broth is also served with accompanying rice. This was followed by the pan fried carrot cake (£6.50) which was superb. Despite the name, the dish has no carrots but is made of pieces of rice cake & shredded radish (Japanese Daikon). These are pan-fried and served with bean sprouts, onions and other condiments. This was delicious and one of the best dishes of the evening. The Char Kuay Teow (£6.60) was just as I remember having in the food courts of Malaysia and Singapore. The noodles were beautifully charred and combined well with the rich, dark and sweet soy sauce giving an intense flavour I have never managed to replicate at home. The seafood was good but not as abundant as it might have been, and the rice noodles soft and slippery like a good cheung fung. This is street hawker food at its best. The Nyonya Ayam Sambal (Chicken Stewed in Rich Coconut Curry @ £6.90) was again amazing. The curry base (rempah) was incredibly complex, with hints of ginger, red chillies, cumin, coriander and belachan (Indonesian shrimp paste). I love belachan - despite the strong fishy smell and flavour, it is definitely an ingredient with a lot of umami. We also ordered a couple of vegetable dishes  the Stir Fried Sambal Cluster Beans and Sambal Ladyfingers priced at £6.50 and £5.80 respectively. They were both excellent, and Charmaine and I had no trouble polishing them off with the extra portions of rice we ordered. The ladyfingers were nicely cooked, still pleasantly firm and not viscous. Charmaine was very impressed with the quality and authenticity of all dishes that we tried, and our dinner companions and I agreed with her heartily. Our meal, at £46.20 for four people, would have been perfect had it not been for the poor level of waiting service. Verdict  Wonderful, authentic Straits Cuisine in modest surroundings, and at very reasonable prices. The unfriendliness of the staff needs to be addressed. A place to explore the still relatively undiscovered Straits Chinese and Peranakan Cuisines in London. I will certainly return.

35diiWK0XyrP8lx98h_IaA.text: I looked on Yelp for something nearby and Rasa Sayang had great ratings.  I tried some dumplings that I thought were terrible, and the Nasi Lemak, which was pretty average.  I guess I wouldn't give it 1 star unless the service was bad, but they were friendly and the service was fine.

ioBBsbGyHMRbIdHQF4YNVA.text: Easily one of the more surprising finds of recent times, this unassuming malaysian diner looks like your usual 'big bowl' fare, but sit down and pick out some gems within the menu, order a pot of tea (or something stronger) and prepare your tastebuds for an adventure.Standout dishes for me were the Home Made Tofu in sweet cucumber and chili dressing, and the Carrot Cake which is actually a savoury fried dish that's both comforting and utterly delicious. I tried some of the less familiar dishes on the menu, so I can't vouch for the 'curry and rice' dishes  I would instead urge you to go with someone equally hungry  and share!For those who like spicy, try the Lontong, which consists of compressed rice and a vegetable curry sauce slightly hotter than the Sun's core. For those with less masochistic tastes, the staff will steer you towards gentler, yet still highly flavoursome food. They (refreshingly) know a lot about what's on the plate, so those with a dairy or gluten intolerance will breathe a sigh of relief as you will be told exactly what to expect.Reasonably priced and beautifully presented, I went here twice in 3 days just to check it was as tasty as I remembered  and it was. Both times I came in starving, and left rather full and satisfied. Five stars!Starter and main coursel for two with tea: around £20would suit: friendly pre-cinema meal, really hungry people. room for large groups downstairs

tJ22DJpWcZDFJjPLyNMI7g.text: Stumbled onto this place, while exploring London's Chinatown, and was very pleasantly surprised.  The upstairs was packed, and so I had to go downstairs to an initially emply dining area.  Well, that room filled up soon.Ordered an Asam fish curry, and loved it.  Just had it with steamd rice.  The curry was very flavorful, had a good sized serving and was cooked with some awesome okra, tomatoes, and eggplant (or should I say aubergines :) ).The rest of the menu looks quite good too.The dessert menu isn't the greatest (for my tastes).  There are great pastry and coffee shops across the main road in the Soho area :)

5Ae7aMeyKXk0KRkReoJWXw.text: I have lived in Singapore / Malaysia and have not really found a place that can make me re-live the culinary experience..This place surprised me.. the portion size is huge, the food is fresh, the food itself is great, the service is prompt and when they say spicy - they mean it (not the European version of spicy)The no-so-good: - The downstairs was not open despite the packed upstairs.- The restaurant was too cold.. most people wore their scarves which is a bit unfair inside a restaurant.- The decor itself is very un-invitingI will certainly go there again!

JmVHS1JtH7MfyAmDOqGmCQ.text: Solid Malaysian food.I can't remember the exact Malaysian names of the dishes, but the rice noodle in curry was sooo good, never had anything like it. and good amount of spice too!my fried rice with satay was okay, the satay was a bit watery and the fried rice tasted like soy sauce..still, the food is good, and if i ever go back, i will definitely try more things here!

gQtqe6bnTDc4U3yH0WSFzA.text: It was pancake day. I saw a sign for Malaysian pancakes. What was I supposed to do? I had to walk in.SO worth it. They've got flavours ranging from exotic (creamed corn and peanuts) to freaking awesome (red bean paste, coconut) to western (like a Malaysian-style crepe).Docked 1 star because I had a quick look at the menu and there were (as with many Asian restaurants) very few vegetarian choices. No biggy. You can just eat pancakes for lunch.

YOEsPzdL5FnGsi68QUx7Fg.text: Introduced by a friend we wandered past the hustle and bustle of china towns main street and ventured into Rasa Sayang.  There were no tables available upstairs so we were shown down to the additional seating, aka the basement.  The place was packed and the last table was in a little cove where I, at a tad over 6 foot, had trouble standing.  It was cosy but fine!We took our seats I ordered, by recommendation, the Roti Canai to kick everything off and the then Tangy Assam Fish Fillet.  The Roti was so buttery it melted in your mouth with the curry sauce.The Fish was awesome and the spice was perfect, packed with flavour.  One of our beers came out a little on the warm side (some people are into that I guess) but the food was GREAT.  The Roti is so moreish I could've eaten that and only that all night long!Good service is nice and sometimes I'm there to enjoy "the dining experience" more often than not if the food is good as long as they bring it out on time and they know when to present the check I'm happy.  This is one of those places! If you're looking for silver service this isn't the place for you! Well Priced and Great food, I'll be back!

exACY-RpOHYxqc_ZKydlkA.text: This was one of the few places we went to more than once on our recent trip to the UK.  IT was amazingly good and the prices were so reasonable it puts all the other places we went in London to shame.  To have this great tasting food and most of it under 10 GBP is amazing.  I spent two weeks in Singapore a couple of years ago and this place took me back to that trip.  The smells, the food, the teh tarik, the tiger beer, all were great reminders.  But the proof is in the pudding.  And it was here.  The only think missing was murtabak.  You must have the carrot cake, or chai tow kway.  And no it is not the sweet cream cheese thing that americans eat for dessert.  It is a savory dish with diakon, lightly fried, with veggies and fish sauce.  It is so yummy and I haven't had it in over two year so this was a real treat.  The curry laksa knocked my wifes socks off.  She loved it.  and it is truly spicy, as it should be and not some watered down version.  The second time we went there we had the Sambal fish, another must have.  The Roti was excellent as well.  Both meals were between 20 and 25 GBP, which is amazingly cheap for this part of town as well as food this good!  I only wish I had the time to try their chili crab and chicken and rice.  Quintessential Singaporean dishes.  Lots of people were eating the chicken and rice, but that is one dish that is always up for debate on how best to prepare and even it eat it!  Others have complained about the service and the decore, but they just don't really get how these types of places work and there is nothing wrong with either.  One other thing about Rasa Sayang that truly reminded me of Singapore was the people eating there.   Chinese,  Malay, Europeans, and Indians were all eating and enjoying the food.Take the nearest tube station to China town and go here!  Go now! Because I'm jealous I can't go myself.

wjobYwH1zv4Yj11cQrqpGA.text: We were meandering through Chinatown and getting more and more hungry due to the smells wafting from various restaurants. We tried to be good and save our appetite for dinner. Unfortunately, all resolve was lost as we stumbled upon this place just outside the gates to Chinatown. One glance of "Mee Goreng" on the menu and the husband was sold. I ordered their fried sambal fish - fantastic! The service was fast and friend and the food was absolutely delicious! Highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Sambal fish with steamed rice.
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Seafood Mee Goreng

9nvmBPN-1uIVM_XUb5R4aQ.text: Honest, common-folk Malaysian dining.I've been quite skeptical about ethnic foods in London, often finding that authenticity is compromised in favor of popularity.  Not Rasa.In many ways stepping into Rasa felt just like dining in Asia - noisy, crowded, but never too busy to accommodate one more guest.  It appears to be a family-owned and run operation.Naturally I'm drawn to the Chinese-influenced side of the menu.  Starting with deep fried chicken wings, I went on to tackle the turnip cake, sator (stinky green) bean stir fry, and beef and rice.  Much attention has been put into the flavoring and variety of ingredients used on each dish.  Portions are a bit meager at times.I'm eager to try out the soup noodles on my next run.

PLh73Ow3qohF0B3tuIfNlA.text: The little Malaysian flag in the window of this restaurant waved at me and yes, it's another of the current wave of Malaysian restaurants opening in the capital. Yay!There is a limited menu specialising in Malaysian hawker (street) food, which happens to be the type of food I miss the most from home.The char koay teow is a benchmark for me as to how good a Malaysian restaurant is and this place gets a B+/A-. I shall be back to sample the rest of the menu which looks promising.

Ik7X0JTwzXuSyYr3zdh6vg.text: I've been to Rasa Sayang several times before and enjoyed it every time time I've gone (when I used to eat flavourful meat dishes). It's pretty inexpensive and filling in a tiny dinning room with more space downstairs.Coming back as a vegetarian wasn't too thrilling, so I reluctantly give 3* instead of 4*. It's a carbo-lovers delight with heaping piles of noodles and a scarcity of much of anything else.The shaved ice with red bean dessert was terrible. The ice was partially crushed and the topping lacked much of any flavor.I can't say I'd return, but it's worth checking out to see if it suits your fancy.

-XmDDLljCtj3qccnsKs5qw.text: If you are around China Town, and never had Malaysian I recommend you to try. Ot you are just craving for some Malaysian Food. Mostly Malaysian Street food. Nasi Lemak, Roti Chanais and noddles. Rasa Sayang was very good. I used to head over here when i want to have some Malaysian food and i didn't have any time time cool. However as time passed, the food here started to taste average. Not 100% authentic and lacking the through Malaysian flavours. Sad actually. It was the nearest Malaysian resaturant from work .

uxdVUtMwma7DA4kzsnxBwA.text: I find it hilarious that Yee Gan comes up as one of the top words in these reviews, yet not suprising. This is a Halal Malaysian joint with pretty standard fare. I had the Char Koay Teow, which are similar to Chinese chow fun or Thai Pad See Ew noodles. It was plentiful, tasty, and inexpensive. What I always like to have in my Asian restaurants of any sort.If you're in the area and overwhelmed by the choices, this would be a good staple and a bit different than your normal chinatown fare.

Q25AaJT4vn8D-RWxqjpV1A.text: I have been there  a few times as wanted  a change from eating Chinese. it's  always  a hot and miss when  I try new dishes. The Nasi Lemak or Nasi Goeeng are OK but chicken  is a bit dry. The beef randeng is good but all the noodles  dish including Laksa were bland and  lack taste or texture. it's  like if they have  different  chefs so not the same standard throughout  the week. Also waiting staff not  good at  handling complaint when I said food was bland and said an earlier customer had praised  the  food so  mine was a first  complaint !  A good waiter would  have  offer a free coffee  or tea to compensate.

WKBjsUClYc2MYmyGhEkOUA.text: Thought we would give this a second chance but never again. My fish ball noodle soup came with an unexpected bunch of metal wires. When I found it I was quite disgusted and also a bit puzzled. I have no idea how you can end up serving soup with wires in them unless the cook doubles as an electrician.I expected a heavy discount to our bill but was only given a whopping 10% off.  Quite disappointed and will avoid next time.

0ysowHftxtXcSYovR4AEUg.text: I've only tried the roti and bubble tea from here, so this isn't the most thorough of reviews. The roti was excellent and I loved the sauce that came along side it. The bubble tea however was a let down...the tapioca was overcooked, making it mushy and frankly, too big to fit through the straw. I looked like an idiot trying to drink it, because it just would not go up no matter how hard I tried, so I resorted to eating them with a spoon and drinking the tea separately.  They also had this weird rule that you had to spend a certain amount per person...I think it was 5 pounds, but because I wasnt eating, I had to order something for someone else and pretend it was for me...just so strange. Our total was over 5 pounds per person in total, but because my order was only 3 pounds, it was not ok it was all a bit odd.

IOHawH0ePb_0iQNL9qSmGA.text: My go-to spot for cheap, delicious Malaysian food in London. The portions are huge and the food is tasty. I had the seafood hor fun (wide flat noodles with seafood and sauce) and the roti canai the last time I was there. I've had most of the noodle dishes, and they don't disappoint. Good for a quick, fulfilling meal!

d9t3gc5CWxM5MV7nOgU6Qg.text: I came to visit London from USA. After reading several reviews, I wasn't sure about this place. After finding no other alternative, I showed up here.Food was great, price was great and girls were really friendly. I have no idea how they server so fast! Every items are good - I ordered several items and each one kicked-a##.

KGtInu_-Ln6Na7P7iDqM8g.text: The food comes super fast because its all pre prepared. I asked for mine spicy, it came mild, I asked for hot sauce so I could spice it up myself, 20 mins later we were done and never got any hot sauce.Not great.

KKEAB0GAP11t3xqf2KiO6g.text: Rasa Sayang kick-started my love of Singapore Laksa. I haven't found a better Laksa anywhere else (including Malaysia, though I have to admit we didn't make it out of the airport).I've yet to try any of the other fare, but it does look tasty and it's nicely cheap making it a good lunch spot.

YXb7EFl39oGpFxKCYNVMnw.text: OMG.  So spicy.  I went with my authentically spicy eating asian friend for dinner here and we nearly cried.The funny chicken and potato spring roll and fried wontons were perfectly edible but my char que teoy was a little bit oily and it was just plain funny watching my friend cry eating his nasi lemak even though he must have had curries since he was born!Otherwise a standard chinese/asian caf layout in china town.  Oh, how I miss Nyonya.

o8duePrECdHQLCuEi0JI3Q.text: My only experience of Malaysian food was a couple of years ago at C&R over in Rupert Court, but I decided to give this place a go as it had such a loyal following. To say I left disappointed is an understatement: I realise that sometimes these places can be a bit hit and miss, as they don't have the same professionalism or service standards control that more expensive establishments strive for but I can forgive a slow waitress service, a forgotten side salad or poor seating if the food was good. Unfortunately it wasn't. The Straits Chicken Curry came out within 3 minutes of ordering and although the sauce was delightfully hot and creamy, the chicken was lukewarm in the middle and drier than a pair of lips in a sandstorm. My partner's Singapore Noodles can only be described as grey in colour and flavour and we've had better in the hundreds of cheap noodle bars. And then to top off the very brief and dissappointing lunch, they somehow lost our order of pandan pancakes and so we waited 15 minutes for something that never arrived. Maybe I'll come back and give these guys another shot as they were busy and I could've caught them on a bad day. I really hope it wasn't through lack of effort on there part. If it was - Shame on you Rasa Sayang! cheap-eat-london.com

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

5jYUE1pRcykRLytuKOnzeA.text: Friends came to visit and they'd randomly stopped in here. The food is solid. On the hot side of spicy, without being overbearing. Super tender beef, a wide selection of not-often-found asian vegetables, etc.There's a tofu and spicy peanut sauce dish that's to die for.Why low stars? It's a bit on the expensive side (£24 for 2 beers, 2 mains, and a single shared starter), it's about as bright as daylight, and the beef dish was swimming in oil. But it's better than most of the stuff around Chinatown. Totally solid, and full of flavour. I'd go back.

9p8rVT2rggX0alCxWke6Sw.text: If you're famished, Rasa Sayang is a great place to dine! I've visited this restaurant countless times and each time, the food didn't take more than 15-20 minutes to arrive. However, when it comes to the food, I don't think Rasa Sayang is one of the best places for Malaysian cuisine in London (though I am from Malaysia myself, so I might be a little critical). Nevertheless, for quick service and satisfying portions, it's a great place to go if you're near Chinatown.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Curry laksa mee and stir-fried sambal cluster beans

VNuZkKnx8tN_3VHtYHgQXQ.text: Affordable Authentic Malaysian food.Can be slow but its worth the wait.Favourite dishes: Laksa, Rendeng beefExpect to spend: £8-10ppConclusion: loved by many malaysians/asians!

IdoUR3ktCqe_h9nrRDX4IA.text: This place is the place to go! It is so delicious and a good price. I was excited because it was all of the dishes that I grew up eating in Singapore and it was up to standards. The meals are really cheap too wit appetizers (I always get the roti canai for 3.90) and meals in the 7.20 range. Really affordable (AND DELICIOUS) for a university student budget. I always bring all of my friends here and even those who have not had Malaysian food, in the end, love it. P.S. Some recommendations are the Nasi Goring, Nasi Lemak, Hokkien Mee, Curry Laksa, among many. P.P.S. Also accepts AMEX!!!!!

6s85LFHaBtdyjlVu0J30KA.text: Not bad, not bad. ordered a indian rojak, quite plentiful. And hokkien fried mee - seafood just a bit skimpy, no lime but have lemon. I love the menu - have to say it's more Singaporean than it is Malaysian. Love the walls decorated with scenes of Singapore and Malaysia. Eh don't pray pray ah, they even have bandung ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Indian rojak
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Singapore hokkien mee

la9rAH-CjrnsITb2E6SiHg.text: Downpour outside so I ducked inside and found a gem. Nice staff, good food served fast. What not to like.

H41MuNU8ozngIqvWrutF7w.text: I always make it a point to come here when in London.  Dishes I love here are the roti canai, chicken rice, and chili crab.Desserts here are fantastic.  I have never had Singaporean desserts before trying them here.  I had the chendol and was so full from entrees, that I couldn't scarf the whole cup down.  Chendol might very well be the best dessert I have ever had!

5Y1QLbRcK_2cExlCwyJjkA.text: Ooh, went here with a friend who is from Singapore, she reckoned the food was pretty good, I did too! Spicy, authentic, tasty, low key, bustling, cheap! Yeah, defo recommend!Ooh one thing, my friend had the Pearl Milk Tea, she reckoned the tapioca pearls were too hard, other than that, great!

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Yummy!
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Roti Canai

-P5ocWIQrPboMDJngvoBDA.text: Had some take out here..the char kuai teow and nasi lemak. Good taste and BIG portions. Decent price. Recommended for some local Malaysian food

Yxb-4zXKYwSi2eLhGhOB-w.text: Seems like it's pretty hit or miss here. On my first visit I had the prawn mee and a friend got the nasi goreng. Both were fairly authentic. Decided to come here again to try the nasi lemak (someone said it was good, LIAR) and was not a happy camper. When we started the meal I thought, okay, this is a 3/5, but as we ate, that number just got lower and lower. 1. The rice was too mushy and didn't taste of much (and we know it's all about the rice) 2. It's served with curry chicken. Really? It's not like they don't have fried chicken on the menu! 3. The sambal they served it with definitely wasn't sambal, it wasn't even chili. I could go on forever about why this dish was just so wrong but basically the only thing right was the sliced cucumber. Feel like the rule is to stick with what you/your friends know!Also, they have sth like a £6 minimum per person which is pretty off-putting, like 'pay up or you're not worth our time'. Eww.

HWdofU0yX1bHaN_KWTxPmQ.text: Still legit after a 2 year hiatus for me. New dish to recommend: veggie kon loh mee with wonton soup. Their fishball and ipoh hor fun soup are still kinda meh but I still dig this place and the service is way friendlier than I remember!

lbNHzfj3e0_C3nIi6JM_rQ.text: I've been here twice, once with my mother who wanted to try Malaysian food, and once alone when I was dying for food in China town.When I went with my mother, who is not an adventurous eater, we played it safe and got the Chicken rice and a soup dish. It wasn't too expensive, the service was cordial and not too wordy (not a huge fan of waiters who fawn over you), and the food was pretty good all around. My mom really enjoyed it, and said it was simple and fresh food.I stopped by again when I was in the neighborhood, just to eat by myself, and had another really good experience. Some places are really hard to eat at when you're alone, but Rasa Sayang is really cool. I had a delicious hokkien mee, which arrived really quickly. It definitely wasn't the best I've ever had, but for the price, it was good value. The waitstaff stayed out of my hair for the most part, but was really quick to respond.Overall, good experiences all around.

3fESLkKq1kYDbffv9GPpzg.text: The food is delicious here, and I've come several times, always with groups of 5-14 people. However, today I came with a group of 12, and the staff told us that we had to order £8 pounds per person. Since not all of us were that hungry, and the cost of an average dish there is just under £8, they were clearly insisting that we order more than we might want to, and as this wasn't up for discussion, we all left. This was sad to me as the food is great and very affordable, but this time the service let us down.

vZSz87SWJprE-xJwzDTQWA.text: Quick glance:+ great for quick bite+ lots of staff+ authentic flavoursFull review:If you are craving for a taste of Malaysia and in a hurry, then come by Rasa Sayang. The venue is brightly lit and clean, and it offers tasty Malaysian dishes at fast-food pace and prices. I came here for a pre-theatre dinner and timing was perfect.

ly2gYiwgmlahKn-9ykkBcQ.text: So I was on facebook and some guy posted a picture of Hainan Chicken Rice, my favourite Singaporean dish (5 star, boo tong kee, chicken rice, on river valley holy motherf*).So I was like Imma have me some chicken rice.SO I went to yelp and looked up the nearest one and I got rasa sayang.1) It's decent chicken rice. The soup was OK, the rice was so-so (not supple enough, not fragrant enough), the chicken was an ample amount given (5-6 thick slices with the skin on top and some nice soya souce, the chili sAUCeee was decent....2) Too expensive. 8 quid for chicken rice? That's like 16 sgd = 4 chicken rices in a kopitiam. WTF.*anyway I realized everything in chinatown/london is expensive. but still. dayum.3) Chicken rice wasn't good nuff for me. I will continue my search to find the best chicken rice in London. K PEACE OUT ^.^*also why is the rice brownish looking? the rice should look yellowy/shiny right? amirite?

Ol20xXm4SY6GW7WK6b5B-w.text: I'm not sure what I was expecting but this was among the strangest and most off-putting dining experiences I've had in a long time. In short we waited forever to have our orders taken, there were chicken bones and chop sticks  on the floor, and when we tried to get out, it took forever to get our check. Unpleasant to say the least!I'm hoping tonight was an off night. Either way I have no plans to go back and won't recommend it.

5_zhKdFsnOiD_J5wWdDotA.text: I'm always looking for a good cheap eat.  My first visit was so so but I was happier with my second.  Four of us went for dinner and got a selection of items:  stir fried morning glory, beef rendang, long bean stir fried with shrimp, singapore noodles, fried chicken with shrimp paste and roti.  I wouldn't say that the food is outstanding but given the prices, it was a good budget find (a little over £60 for 4 people isn't bad!)

Zdi7sAnBirwEAruO9hNV7A.text: I was looking for a good place to eat, with decent portions and that also didn't break budget. Rasa Sayang was all of the above, and was very please with the food for less than £17. I was able to have a starter, main course and dessert!

00ShMJM2UiyduhoOQXnLOA.text: If you're out for some good, cheap Malaysian food in central, then Rasa Sayang is it. You'd be a fool to go anywhere else, really.Get the teh tarik. Get some roti canai. Order the drink called the 'milo dinosaur'- a drink that I can only describe as a cold hot chocolate with chocolate sugar on top - just so your bill can say:DINOSAURTEH TARIKROTI CANAI NASI GORENGCURRY LAKSAIf you don't like chocolate, it's sure to give you a chuckle, at least. But who doesn't like chocolate? People who hate Jesus, that's who.________________________________________________This review was: [x] Useful

_EAaAFUlrwkenrfy9pGxJQ.text: Good Malaysian food in London has been somewhat elusive ever since the closure of Satay Stick (on Dering Street I believe...I still remember how delicious their chicken wings were) back in 1999 and, whilst there is a plethora of Thai, Cantonese, Japanese and Vietnamese restaurants around, Malaysian restaurants are comparatively few and scattered around. I used to like Kiasu in Bayswater before it got closed down for reasons including, but not limited to: mouse in sauce pot; cockroach eggs in prawn cracker baskets; rodent droppings all over kitchen.  Their owner is now in prison I believe.I'd been meaning to check out Rasa Sayang for a while but never got round to it, one of the main reasons being that it's Halal.  Not that I have anything against Halal food, but I have to say that Hokkien Mee just isn't the same without the fried crispy pork lard garnish.  The interior is pretty standard, not dissimilar to nearby C&R Cafe, but somewhat more spacious.  I've enjoyed my two meals here - the beef rendang is well-flavoured (also very spicy) and the Hainan gai fun (steamed chicken rice) is generously portioned with tasty rice, and comes with the soup (unlike some places).On food alone, the three stars may seem a little stingy.  Generally, I turn a blind eye to sub-par service, but Rasa Sayang is really poor in this department.  The last time I went, the waiter was rather unfriendly at the beginning (granted, it was Friday night) and shoved the two of us on a 4-person table already occupied by two.  This was in spite of the fact that there was a free two-person table downstairs.  When it came to ordering I could still detect a hint of contempt from the waiter.  Then the food came.  Food should not be lukewarm.  I understand that Friday night is a stressful time, but even so, there is a basic standard and Rasa Sayang failed to meet it.  Cheap and good, perhaps, but I am on the fence about going back.

XDd74TlHxtQZVKU9mQSOVA.text: I came back from Malaysia with a real taste for Nasi Lemak, and an uncertainty as to where I was going to be able to scratch the itch. Thank goodness for Rasa Sayang. This is far and away my favorite Malaysian place in London, and the high quality of the Nasi Lemak is a big part of that equation.But there's more. The Roti Canai is as glorious as any I've ever had, and I liked the Char Kuay Teow. I want to try everything in this place (but then again, it's hard not to get Nasi Lemak, so who knows if I'll manage to try much else- OK, maybe the Laksa).Finally, get a cup of Teh Tarik to wash it all down and you will be glad you did. Now if I could only find a place that serves century eggs on a stick at 3am, my Malaysian experience will be complete.

EXG0Tn_WWFxZMkyD-KnasA.text: My, how Chinatown has changed in the 10 years since I've lived in London. Back then, I would've given my left arm for a tasty Singo-Malay-Indonesian spot in this area. I won't pretend I can judge Rasa's authenticity, but I will say the food is extremely well made and bursting with flavor. Seafood lovers should dive into the Tamarind Assam Fish, as tender fish in fragrant, chile-filled sauce is a particular specialty of this region. For dessert, you can't go wrong with the perennial Kueh Dadar, which Rasa does amazingly well. I'm not sure if that's real pandan juice in there or just artificial flavoring, but the filling is spot on.Service is what you expect for a bustling Asian restaurant: brisk, efficient, but not altogether unfriendly. The clientele were a mix of Asians and non-Asians, but even if you're dining alone, this is a place where you can really enjoy yourself.

Rn43Olpa1kipULyowHJ3Ig.text: Summary based on one post theatre dinner:--ok food--ok prices for area--average staffStaff informed me when I showed up that I had to finish up in 1/2 hour, which was ok I guess since I was dining alone and just getting an all in one noodle dish. If I go again I'd try to avoid a time constraint.I'd come back to try more things, so recommended on that score, especially if nearby C&R is closed.

7EDyF5YB1IfvNkpJlfGogw.text: nasi lemak no taste and sweetened.Curry lasa okay.Mixed seafood Prawn fried noodle with egg ,not much ingredients

DwYkttpu7GtLem0FbWOJoA.text: Busy place in Chinatown with street level and basement seating. Pretty simple interior, service and food presentation, but the Nasi Lemak I had was very very close to what I had in Malaysia, so full points for authenticity. The desert (Cendol Ice, shaved ice with coconut cream, syrup, beans and jelly) was okay, but the beans were undercooked and the ice has sat too long which made the dessert watery and the ice clumpy. Overall a pretty good choice if one wants to try authentic Malaysian cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Cendol Ice (very similar to an Ice Kacang)
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Deluxe Nasi Lemak

1repfs__W6oW7v3bvvmDag.text: We had:Char Kuey Teow ： Hokkien MeeIce Kacang ： Onde OndeThey are all nice and authentic, especially the char kuey Teow. Nice service and the crowd keeps coming in. There was even a Malaysian tour dining while we were there.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. One last Malaysian fix before we leave. We had:  Char Kuey Teow : Hokkien Mee Ice Kacang : Onde Onde
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

aYFUc33N_UzRQMvmWDyPww.text: The food came out very fast and the portions were pretty large for the cheap price. The servers had a very deep accent but they were super friendly. The place was pretty busy around 7pm. The menus were very unique because each food item had its own picture and description of everything in it.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Char kway teow

ibcnGtfTV-t7C4bwb_IfwQ.text: Restaurant is quite small on the edge of chinatown, would really recommend it to anyone who loves Malaysian or Indonesian food. Sayang means something like honey and my goodness the food really was darling! I don't know why I have not been here before, I have definitely added it to my favourites for London restaurants. Besides the authetically served dishes I would also induldge yourself in some of their desserts, really really nice! Since I am a big fan of chendol and the shaved ice creams south east asia is so well known for - I could have this all day every day - truly found my little sayang downtown

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Chendol ice cream - like whut
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Whooo

GHvUV27Le2kcc5W9zm7cHQ.text: As a Malaysian that lived in Malaysia for 28 years and been living in London for 9 years, I can gladly say that most dishes served here are very authentic. On my fifth visit recently, I found that one of the main waitresses to be a bit patronising and talked down to us when we were ordering. Plus, she had a cold and kept on sniffing her nose, which is always unbecoming in such a busy restaurant. Also, to this particular waitress (I didn't get her name), please treat your customers equally regardless of genders, ethnicities, appearances, preferences, etc. I would have given 4 stars if not for that bad service. You don't talk back in Chinese thinking that your customer (me) won't understand it. You're welcome.

brTv7UqZyu_BFGLfcYA_JA.text: Standard oil-slick aside, the laksa was decent here, though I should have gone for the hainan chicken and nasi lemak as recommended. The restaurant smells great!Big bowl of spicy soup and noodles will keep you going during Britain's rain showers.The staff speak Cantonese, and are rather friendly. I'm coming back to try their spicy chicken and seafood noodle soup as well.Everything is around £7 or 8.

GSvGTpjryLQbrZ62dDa6yw.text: Food was ok. Service extremely poor. If you're looking for a nice meal, don't come here. The service will put you off and it will spoil your night.

id8Yc0jsRaGUDXklq_yFHg.text: Authentic Singaporean/Malaysian food that reminds of home. If you never had Singaporean food before, then you must might be disappointed because it's slightly different from the typical Chinese food you may see. I had Chicken Rice and Teh Tarik. The portion was generous, the chicken and rice were well seasoned. It was also served with chili and ginger, which were really delicious too.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

SKVRN4bRmhf-WXJtK9OxsA.text: This is a halal restaurant, and numerous families filtered through at lunchtime. We were in Malaysia earlier this year, and were ecstatic to see nasi lemak on their menu. The excitement was short-lived, however, as it arrived with large, dry chunks of chicken breast. The entire dish lacked depth and spice of flavor, including the pickled vegetables. Their kway teow was chock full of squid that could not be substituted with chicken, and tasted blandly monotonous. Malaysian food is known for its harmonious mix of delicious spices. This...tasted like soy sauce.Tables are positioned too close for comfort, and you may need to shimmy your way to your seat at someone's shoulder. To their credit, however, orders arrive prompt and piping hot. The noise from talkative customers, however, can be overwhelming. Ask for the bill at your table. When it arrives, pay at the front.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Kway teow and nasi lemak

Z_Cllbu_eutmH-kbc6ChHw.text: We arrived at this restaurant around 830 on a Tuesday night and the restaurant still had many patrons. Like most of the eateries in London, this was very tightly packed. We ordered the curry chicken, hainan chicken, and bread with the curry dipping sauce. Our food was served promptly and the entrees were served before the appetizer. I thought the curry chicken portion was plentiful and I left very full, however DH hoped for a bigger portion of his dish. As far as flavor and style of the dishes, I have only one other Malaysian restaurant to compare it to in NYC. The curry flavor of my dish was very strong, which I prefer, but it did seems bit oily. Still, it was nice to try Malaysian food in a different country and see the variances. If we have the chance to come back to London, we would certainly give this place another shot.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Soy sauce chicken
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Curry chicken

0iCuljUqbeo29j5FfQ4zAA.text: Been here twice now and it definitely does a good job of reminding you of Singapore and Malaysia if you miss either.  Is it "straight out of a hawker stall" authentic?  No, but it is really, really good for being a world away in London.  So yes, definitely come, and eat everything.  You'll start to get a sense of why so many of us rave about the food of SE Asia.

c_xA6MZ5OGCmGU4zDdXzIw.text: You know you are in the right place when most of the customers are Asian, some were even Malays. Better still, talking to two Brits (Caucasian) in the table next to me, I found out that they are regulars; and one of them even lived in Malaysia and is married to a Malaysian. I had a spicy chicken and seafood noodle dish that was very good. The rest of the dishes looked and smelt great. I will definitely have to come back to try the rest.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Curry Chicken and Seafood Noodle with Rojak

rD_SMzCpGBusEeOYBeLLBQ.text: I got the Nasi Lemak as recommended and I really liked it! The coconut rice is delicious and the curry is very good. The only downside would be the price. I paid about $19 for that and water (which I forget you have to pay for in London).

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Nasi Lemak

IdCi5FCx_01DgiQLav_xsQ.text: we were in London for 5 days, and we visited this place everyday. As a Malaysian, i was very happy with the food and with the price. Love the Hokkian mee and Loh mee. I have my cravings satisfied.

cv3jVtnbj-YwWsLZKbvYQQ.text: Love this place.  Love that there are so many Malay and Singaporean people eating here.  Love the well intentioned but slightly disorganized service. And especially love the food.  This is a great place for SE Asian comfort food so expect it to be a little spicy. Great rendang, great noodles, and the fish stew is excellent.  Recommend eating family style so come with friends. Definitely one of the restaurants in London that I will return to; this was my second time.  Also recommend C&R on Rupert Court.  Price is around 15 GBP per head, which is cheap by London standards.

f1-HkGd1qDDY81BMUxxfhg.text: NOW THIS IS WHAT I AM TALKING ABOUT. This is THE BEST place in London to get authentic Singaporean cuisine. I'm born and bred Singaporean and this is where I go when I am homesick. The roti canai and laksa are pretty damn close to the real thing back home. As is their char kway teow and various mee gorengs. You can even get Ice Milo or Milo Dinosaur! And it's not just me who thinks it's authentic. Everytime I go there I always hear other Singaporean accents from the patrons around me and once even bumped into an old classmate from Singapore there! I take every new friend of mine to eat here seeing as they probably will never be able to visit me in Singapore so this is the next best thing.

Zg80V0LQ8vKbtmQQNn1PQw.text: Fairly good malaysian restaurant by London's standards. Their chow kuay teow is especially good, better than C&R (the other malaysian restaurant I have tried in chinatown), but their price is a little dearer than C&R when service charge is included.

snmOsc0aJ-M0UGbaLyQJwA.text: Went to my go-to Malaysian restaurant and ordered my go-to dish:- Lor MeeA steaming bowl of crispy chicken, plentiful noodles and spices drowned in a thick brown soup, this is a perfect meal for a cold October night after a long day's work. It has a herbal, almost medicinal quality seldom found in other dishes and brings warmth and comfort. On this occasion it could have used a little more salt but having sampled this many times before I know this to be an anomaly.I walked an extra ten minutes past a string of other restaurants having decided on this for dinner and it was utterly worth it.

byGiwesUPgG-nOVpSNDGgw.text: I came here to try the chili crab, for a whole crab and 6 mantou, it was only £20, which is a pretty good deal in my opinion. It was good but messy dish, and as good as the fried mantou (fried brioche) was, I think I would've preferred to eat it with rice. I've never had the real thing in Singapore so cant tell you if it's any good in comparison but I can say that this didn't blow me away, hence the 3 stars. I do want to come back for the roti canai and the chicken, seems like those were the more popular dishes in the restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

xMh7eS98RejakCmQ2KyH4Q.text: Small restaurant but it has a huge menu. I tried the Singapore Curry Laksa when I was here and the broth was very flavourful. It had a good taste to it and thick broth with the addition of coconut milk. Unfortunately, that was the only thing that was good with the curry laksa. The noodles were overcooked making it extremely soggy and the shrimp serving was a joke. I got 2 half of a shrimp of the size of a quarter (American coin size). Another thing that made it rather bland ( not the soup) was the fact that everything was probably cooked on a hot water prior to adding the soup  thus making all of the other items tasteless. The shrimp, tofu, noodles had a bland taste to it. The wait staffs were friendly and quick. During a lunch rush, I was able to sit, order and leave within 30 minutes. I'll probably come back and try something else in the near future but noodle soup won't be one of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Rafles curry laksa , great broth but overcooked and soggy noodle

1sArwPV7-2UQ1-1_xLPCmg.text: This place was just okay. Service wasn't great, and the prices were higher in the restaurant than advertised online, which was a bit annoying. I ordered the Malaysian hokkien mee, which had promised of seafood, specifically prawns and squid. lol and behold, two prawns, 0 squid, but quite a few pieces of chicken that were not very appetizing. The noodles and the broth were tasty, but those hardly require much effort. My friend also ordered the chicken wontons, but they just didn't taste right, and the wrapper was so over cooked it was like knives. There may be a great dish for you here, but I wouldn't come back honestly. I can get better food for better prices elsewhere.

EySlyNbIgJL1mzujaoiFBA.text: Delicious!! I was really surprised to see an average rating of only 3.5. The laksa is yummy, the roti canai is scrumptious, as was the kangkong belacan (morning glory with dried shrimp). Prices are very reasonable.

MjzWhPBtblfecIRHc40iQg.text: My friend had Rasa Sayang bookmarked because of the Singapore Chili Crab and at £15.90, it was definitely a steal, considering these dishes normally are around $50.The four of us came in for a late dinner at around 9:30 on a Wednesday. Although it was late, there were still quite a few tables dining.I ordered the Char Kuay Teow with Hainanese Chicken. They really love soy sauce here because the chicken (which was dry) was drowning in it, and the noodles also had too much soy sauce. If they lightened up on it, then it has the potential to be pretty good - the noodles had a good consistency to it, and the overall flavor was great.I tried the sauce from the chili crab (was too lazy to actually have a crack at the crab), and it was flavorful. It had the perfect amount of spiciness to it, and the eggs made the sauce smooth and creamy. While I probably wouldn't come back for the noodles/chicken, I wouldn't mind having some of that chili crab next time!

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Singapore Chilli Crab
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Char Kuay Teow with Hainanese Chicken

Kl7pj8RjdE3Rm8LC-6S-kg.text: Great food with an amazing variety of vegetarian options for a traditional restaurant. The portions for the laksa soup were massive and they're generous with the veg they put in so it's not all noodles. The restaurant itself is no frills and the basement seating is pretty gloomy! The service was nice but since we were seated downstairs it was tough to get the waiter's attention which wasn't ideal. I'll probably be back for the cheap and yummy food but probably take it to go as it wasn't brilliant service or a particularly charming location.

-ibPRvzGRZwWswNZwXZHKA.text: This is one of the best Malaysian restaurants in town I would say.  What you want from a Malaysian restaurant is cheap, big plate and fills your stomach just like how the street food and most restaurants are in Malaysia.  OK, fine it is not 'authentic, authentic' for a Malaysian but guess what, this is not Malaysia.  To those who are new to Malaysian food, this is definitely a good place to start.  The service here is fast, no frill and most importantly the staff here is much better than their rival restaurant C&R.  So if you want a more polite wait staff, come here.  I think the food is roughly about the same as C&R but I would come here with my other international friends so I don't get embarassed with impolite Malaysians in the other restaurant.  The things that you should definitely try here is the Hainanese Chicken Rice.  The chicken must be succulent and the chicken in this place is definitely it.  I think it is one of the best place for a hainanese Chicken rice due to the moist chicken.  Choose the drumstick / thigh part for more flavour.The Wat Tan Hor (Fried rice noodle with seafood gravy) is definitely one of the best in Chinatown.  Just fills you up with all the goodness of the gravy.  I would definitely give this a try.Get the the normal nasi lemak and not the special one.  I don't know why I pay more for the seafood but the squid that came with it was too big and I couldn't even chew it.  Avoid but try the normal one.  The special one just comes with beef rendang and that is why it is 'special'.I suppose you should just order the beef rendang itself with plain rice.  The beef rendang of course should be ordered as well since you are in a Malaysian restaurant.  Not too dry but the meat is still tender and with a good spicy gravy.  I am unsure what to say for the Char Kuay Tiau (Stir Fried rice noodles).  It is good but not much 'wok hei' (charred wok flavour).  That said, it fills you up and you get to select the special one with big prawns.  Stir fry I would say is sometimes inconsistent as it is sometimes good but other times, the chef just didn't put much love into it.  But do give it a try.Vegetable wise, definitely give the Morning Glory 'Kang Kung' with shrimp paste (belancan) a try.  Equally as good is the okra with shrimp paste (belacan).  Both are definitely favourites amongst Malaysians.If I get the chance again to choose the special meal deal with special versions of the main with drinks and dessert, I would not choose it.  The dessert that comes with it is definitely not worth it.  The green kueh dadar lacks in flavour and coconut taste.  Don't get get me started with the 'cendol'.  The ice shaving is pre-done and kept in a freezer so it is basically a big lump of ice smothered with syrup on top of a bed of cendols etc.  Very hard to eat when the ice is so hard.  Not worth it.  Avoid these 2 if possible but try the other desserts.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

8BM2lsur1yhOVwnB5OoTIQ.text: Reliably authentic and no thrills. Do not focus much on presentation but the flavours are strong and the food hearty. I've been here a few time over several years and not been disappointed yet. Laksa soup was very good, a bit spicy. The Sambal vegetables are a great side dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

u1fvYJGSytBugma_70e3kw.text: This is the real thing.  If not in Singapore, this is the place to go.  5 stars.  Wish I could find Singaporean food this tasty in California.Atmosphere is a bit noisy and loud.  Management should come up with a plan to install a couple sound absorbing panels or something.  There is a secret little dining room down below if you don't mind eating in a basement.

yi9Alzuq33Pd1Mf1U6wyeA.text: Food used to be really good but the quality and authenticity of it has decreased over the years

6La9nZ_1NYXMkE8qimYhow.text: This is a halal Malaysian restaurant. We ordered hokkien mee, seafood hor, curry laksa hofun and Indian rojak. The Indian rojaks came after all the noodles but it was okay . The hokkien mee was very salty. We were not able to finish it because of that. The scrimps in the curry were not fresh and it was mushy. The Seafood hor and curry noodles tasted alright, except the hokkien mee. Staffs were friendly and toilet was clean. It was an okay visit but I won't go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Seafood hor
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Curry hor
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Hokkien mee

BChX4Cy_7f8baA5ayIiI2A.text: We only tried two dishes, shrimp chow fun and Hoinan chicken. The latter was not that great, but the chow fun is decent.  Price is good but the basement venue is surprisingly congested and kind of uncomfortable. In case of fire, it would not be a good thing.Getting used to American style, the tight space in UK restaurant just got me very nervous. Cannot believe UK allows so many tiny restaurants and basement dining!Service is ok. A lot of people! Will go back to check it out. However, so far, 3 stars!

Am4kZzMRNHyBmKar_7IGPw.text: Good food, but ambiance was nonexistent...this place is definitely no frills. If they worked on what this place looked like, it would be more of a hit. Regardless, the portions were HUGE for a lot of the menu options and included a ton of stuff. The beef rendang was full of flavor, and so were the other dishes that I do not remember the names of. Prices for what you get are extremely worth it. If this place looked nicer, it would definitely deserve 4 stars in my book...but many people on different occasions said how good it was, so I guess it's already a hit.

kPOitPhvs0BJEJgJf1uz5A.text: Food was quite good, to be honest, generous portion!We had chow kuey diao, fish ball noodle soup, Loh mee, and oyster omelette. All tasted quite good but obviously you can tell it was not a healthy meal (like any Oriental food, focus in flavour and heat).The milk tea was good too :)4 stars because the kuey diao could see more meat/seafood in it, and the Loh mee can see a little more veggies. Maybe overall less salt too :)Certainly recommend though, especially in London this would be one of the rare gems for decent Asian food!

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Recommend a visit :)
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Bit heavy on the seasoning but good
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Love a good drink!

_gcLaUtVm9n8A3xBfIcdLQ.text: If you've no idea what Malaysian or Singaporean food IS (rather than "roughly Chinese"), you may leave a bit disappointed.  The cuisine is as specific as the places themselves, and so deserving of a unique yard stick.  Here's my quick run-down of the place:First - ambiance is terrible.  But it doesn't really matter in this case, it's food and company.Second - the food itself is very good.  Not great, but very good.  The meats are tender and the fish tastes fresh.  The noodles are pretty standard, and the composition of dishes are complex enough to keep you interested, but I wouldn't call it amazing.Third - the service is perfectly fine.  Very attentive, but in the way that diner waiters are attentive: they give you what you need, but don't expect a friendly chat about all 10 of their hot noodle dishes.Fourth - the sweet stuff is nice and interesting, but by no means best in class.  The deserts can be had better elsewhere, but good enough to give a go when your second stomach requires some filling up at the end of the meal.Fifth - price is right.  Nothing too expensive here, and portion size is good for what you get.Four stars - authentic, very good food at the right price without any frills.

vzlhlCx2FZ2YuYRkwcknGw.text: Hokkien chicken rice is a must for anyone hasn't been to a Malaysian/Singaporean Chinese restaurant. Prawn Mee (prawn, fish balls, fried tofu, vegetables, egg noodles, seafood) is the one of the best dishes I have had on a cold night. Spicy but not too spicy.

qlONMXJJnZlJAhUivNm75g.text: Rasa Sayang is one of those no frill no fuss restaurants serving a good variety of Malaysian and Singaporean dishes at a really budget friendly price. Food isn't exceptional but generous and adequate flavour to leave you satisfied. It's home comfort food renowned for it's big bowls of noodles and one plate dishes. The menu can be overwhelming as there are so many choices, even dessert which is quite rare. On the positive note you can be sure to find something you like.Service is very efficient and friendly too. Food served quick and with two floors, there's barely a wait for a table when things get busy although I have seen a short queue forming outside sometimes. .Teh tarikHighly recommend getting a Malaysian milk tea. Lovely, full bodied and sweeten by strong notes of condensed milk making it incredibly tasty. Comes hot or cold.Curry chee Cheung fun. Not the best in presentation. Expect no more than a few basic steamed rice flour pancakes rolled up and the curry sauce poured over it. All the flavour was contained within the fragrant spicy curry sauce itself. Something incredibly simple but turned out to be a nice comforting dish.Indian rojak This was delicious. Almost like onion Bhajis being deep fried and being crisp on the outside but more eggy and doughy in the inside. What made it more enticing was the lovely peanut sauce on top adding more depth and flavour through its sweet spiced nuttiness flavours, beautifully contrasted with the refreshing cucumbers and blanched beansprouts underneathLor mee. Being a big lover of thick sauce based dishes things I was really satisfied with this dish. Lovely thick rounded yellow wheat noodles in a starchy gravy made from the remaining braising juices from the five spice chicken. The gravy had depth from the chicken and array of spice. It was salted nicely with soy and sweetened by rock sugar. Being starchy it held its heat in quite well even though we had it last. The chicken was tender and flavoursome from the braising process and it was a generous portion too.Fried fish bee hoon. Lovely flavours arising from the m broth that was filled with nice aromas of fish and milkiness from the evaporated milk. It would have nicer if it was richer in flavour but for the price I didn't expect an amazing version. Together with the pickled salty mustard greens it became very appetising. Never been a big fan of thin rice vermicelli but being thin and having the ability to hold more of it in on a pair of chopsticks, it blended really well with all the assorted greens and fish without slipping away.Kangkong balacan Also known as morning glory cooked in shrimp paste. Sadly it was disappointing. The greens itself was a bit old and tough, full of fibers and not possible to chew through completely. It also lacked wok energy so flavours did not infuse it completely although seasoning was spot on.Kueh dadar This was incredible for those who have a sweet tooth like me. Nice thin bouncy pancakes with aromas of pandan although light in flavour. It worked really well against the rougher filling of rich shredded coconut drenched in caramelised palm sugar. Be careful. It's very sweet!Bubar pulut hitam Very similar to a rice pudding but with a more pronounced texture of the individual grains of the red rice being less starchy. It was warm and comforting being creamed by the nice fragrant coconut milk. Flavours were nice much lighter although very filling.Rasa Sayang is a place I keep returning to especially when I can't decide where to eat last minute. With such a large range of dishes on their menu from curries, light soup noodles to simple stir fries, it's easy to satisfy most of my hunger cravings and hard to disappoint. Seasoning is always spot on, nothing too salty or bland. The place is swimming with students because it is so budget friendly and portions are very generous too. One day I hope to have tried everything on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Lor Mee
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Curry chee Cheung fun.
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom. Fried fish bee hoon.

4GYaCIkjhGIbSTPWodhniw.text: Great prices and great food. The place is small so be aware, but if you can put up with close seating and occasionally listing to a conversation other than yours go for it! I was originally trying for Roti King, but that line was a total disaster. Booked it over to Rasa and don't plan to beheading back to Roti. Great place!

j4G0IUlKzPsj2grC9CVnDQ.text: Authentic Malaysian food in the middle of China Town. You know the food is authentic when the majority of the diners are Malaysians living in London. I tried the deluxe seafood set menu for £16.99. It came with a drink, main and desert. My main was the Malaysian thick sauce noodle called Lor Mee, which was huge and a bit too rich for my taste. My friend who also had the same menu as me and he loved it. I didn't like the idea that the waiting staff are too rushy rushy. They seemed to want you to get out as fast as possible. The drink, main and desert all came out at the same time. I will come back again some other time to give this restaurant another chance. There's potential here, but it was let down by the service.

photos.caption: Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rasa Sayang - London, United Kingdom

S_xJUtxhYlVyOosR_uAHNQ.text: Excellent fusion dishes and great service. Reasonabe price and good portion. Too bad discovered the place on our last night in London. Will definitely go back!!!!!

OeYVC3sDXAdnF5YTx2MexQ.text: service was friendly and prompt. very busy restaurant, tasty but not very authentic chicken satay was not really marinated, roti canai curry. too much lemongrass flavor would not call it singaporean or malaysian curry at all. chicken wings were freshly fried but not marinatedtasteless deep fried wings. morningglory vegetables fried in belachan was delicious though and teh tarik was luke warm.meal for two was about 45 GBP so not too disappointed. would not make it a point to return.

GVkkTjJJzdQCZobcpxL5Qg.text: One of my favourite restaurants in London. The food is consistently good and is very reasonably priced. It is has been recommended in multiple write-ups in Timeout, Evening Standard etc. My 2 colleagues were both brought up in Malaysia and also rate it as one of, if not the best Malaysian restaurants in town. It makes for a nice change to the standard Chinese food that you get in the majority of China town restaurants. In my opininion their best dishes are the Char Kway Teow, Beef Rendang, Laksa Noodle Soup, Nasi Goreng, and the Roti Chenai. The Singapore noodles, Hkien Mee and Nasi Lemak also seem quite popular but I'm less fussed. Will be going back before too long I'm sure.

8-8gObR-SLKgE9qV3ti-9g.text: Fantastic restaurant, food was excellent, staff was very nice n helpful compare to the chinese restaurant around, will defo go thr again

owl7x-MVVx9GuE_px6wlnA.text: The restaurant reminds me of elbowing for a table at a food hall in Asia - but it's crowded so that's a good sign for me. I ordered the roti canai and char kway teow. The roti canai was piping hot and had a good chilli kick to it. The char kway teow was nice, but needed more seafood and perhaps some fresh chives to freshen it up a bit. My partner ordered the chicken wings and hokkien mee. The chicken wings were nicely spiced, but the hokkien mee was too salty and lacked flavour, it was really just a bowl of salty sloppy noodles. I'd come back to try other dishes as I like Malaysian and haven't yet found a decent priced alternative.

jSmMuUX2j7r_LAMTi93dFg.text: my regular place whenever i am London, very authentic and grateful to my malaysian (UK resident now) who brought me here.

SVy08FtRprwvRLxT_tfB2A.text: i was brought here by someone i've known for a very long time and his partner ... they were, apparently, regulars ... this is a small-ish restaurant with a rather large menu for such a small place.  i had the soup kambing (which was tasty and substantially less greasy than at other places.  i didn't try other dishes during this visit so i'll have to return another time and try some more.  reasonably priced, too.
